block.p: The Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, measuring 57,000 square feet, are the culmination of a 15-year, $220 million effort.
1926 -- Meant to evoke a setting from classical antiquity, a skylighted atrium (left) houses mainly Roman art.
1954 -- The atrium becomes a restaurant (left). Major classical holdings are removed from display.
Highlights of the Galleries
1. Column, Temple of Artemis at Sardis Greek, 300 B.C. Stands about 12 feet tall in the museum but was originally more than 58 feet tall. Its vegetal pattern is exceptionally elaborate.
2. Veiled and Masked Dancer Greek, third-second century B.C. Layers of clothing sheathe a professional dancer, an entertainer common in ancient Alexandria.
3. Frescoes From a Bedroom at Boscoreale Roman 40-50 B.C. Frescoes creating the illusion of receding space decorated a bedroom in a Roman villa near Pompeii.
4. Garland Bowl Roman, late first century B.C. Four separate slices of glass were joined together, and a thin glass garland was affixed to each quadrant.
5. Chariot Etruscan, sixth century B.C. Probably a parade chariot. Its panels depict episodes from the life of Achilles.
6. Emperor Constantine I Roman, A.D. 325-370 The long face and neat hairstyle of this portrait of the first Christian emperor are meant to evoke earlier, effective emperors.
7. Support for a Water Basin (Porphyry) Roman, Second century A.D. Porphyry was highly regarded as a stone because of its association with royalty and authority.

8. Sarcophagus With the Triumph of Dionysus and the Four Seasons (Badminton Sarcophagus) Roman, A.D. 260-270 In a celebration of pleasure, Dionysus, god of wine, is depicted at the center, riding a panther, with Pan, the goat god, nearby. On the left are figures for winter and spring, on the right, summer and fall.

9. Emperor Trebonianus Gallus Roman, A.D. 251-253 One of a small number of nearly complete bronze statues from the third century. The cropped hair and beard were favored by soldier emperors of the age.
10. Youthful Hercules Roman, A.D. 69-98 Young Hercules, with a lion skin draped over his arm, probably once decorated a public bath.
11. Dionysus Leaning on the Figure of Spes (Hope) Roman, 27 B.C.-A.D. 68 Dionysus stands with a female figure, which may have been added to support the outstretched arm.
Diagram of the Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art highlighting locations of the art listed above.
(Source by Metropolitan Museum)
